posts.name: Alex Cormier
posts.cooked: Which CAD system do we all prefer nowadays? Also, do you have a keyboard shortcut list that you look at to help during the process?

Since the GrabCAD workshop shut down in 2023, more people have been moving to Onshape. The file-sharing system is excellent, and tools like Featurescripts and FRCDesignlib/MKCad simplify workflows. While some teams remain loyal to SolidWorks (such as ours), Onshape has grown significantly and offers an easier entry point for training due to resources like FRCDesign.org, which surpasses many FRC-specific SolidWorks offerings. Additionally, SolidWorks' file-sharing systems are intriguing; we've tried 3DExperience, which is somewhat clunky, and CacheCAD, which performs well.
I love Onshape extraordinarily because it's widely used, it's a web-based CAD software, and FRCDesign.org is a fantastic resource.

I also highly recommend Onshape. I've found its workflow exceptional for FIRST Robotics Competition, collaboration is unmatched, and the learning curve is easy to navigate, especially with resources like this link [http://frcdesign.org] and MCAD available. Another advantage is its broad compatibilityâ€”it works well on everything from a school Chromebook to a $2000 custom PC with minimal issues and maintains consistent performance.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: OnShape is becoming our main tool, but my brain is resisting the switch from Inventor.

posts.cooked: Not really, but making an account is free and easy. Hereâ€™s a PDF with them, but honestly since itâ€™s integrated and easily accessible from any page, I wouldnâ€™t bother keeping it up in this form. Keyboard shortcuts.pdf (81.3 KB)

Hereâ€™s an official one-page view of the keyboard shortcuts for Onshape from 2017. Hereâ€™s an unofficial one for 2025: Onshape Keyboard Shortcuts (2025-04-19).pdf. Image details: ae5e5ae902f58aad3f7f1446e19790c73b0faf92 374x500. Another image: 584x500. And another: 748x1000. Hereâ€™s an image showing the shortcuts. Onshape also shows most shortcuts when you click on the command.

posts.name: Dillon
posts.cooked: We use Fusion 360 because all of our mentors are familiar with it. We had an idea for next year to possibly use a mix of Fusion and Onshape. Also, in our school, we learn both Fusion and Onshape, so everyone has a pretty good idea of how to use bothâ€”even if they arenâ€™t on design.

Onshape is horrible! I keep capping things over and over againâ€”no crashing or hanging. Iâ€™m addictedâ€”I can do it on my phone, school Chromebook, and home desktop without an extra app. Itâ€™s too convenient. The workflow from FRCDesign is solidâ€”it keeps me from getting trapped and ragequitting. Simplified models in FRCDesignlib & MKCad cut down on lag, making dopamine hits tighter. Featurescripts let me focus on important decisions, keeping my Cad sessions less boring and more addictive. Once you get started onshape... thereâ€™s no going back. (Partially kidding) But seriously, Onshape is just fantastic, especially with FRCDesign.

posts.name: Phong Nguyen
posts.cooked: Those scripts significantly increase regeneration times. Our hopper cad this year achieved impressive regeneration times, reaching up to 18 seconds at one point. However, itâ€™s worth noting that this may have been due to the freshmen team focusing on optimizing the system and implementing over a billion transformations.
you gotta be careful with them for sure but with proper workflow and some experience knowing which ones to use and which ones are unperformant onshape can be fairly performant and extremely capable
Soren_1: How am I supposed to break my addiction? This is unfortunately too relatable.
